column1: The Great Migration was the movement of 6 million African-Americans out of the rural Southern United States to the urban Northeast
column3: and West that occurred between 1910 and 1970. Blacks moved from 14 states of the South
column6: Louisiana and Georgia. Census figures show that African Americans went from 52.2% of the population in 1920 to 45.3% of the population in 1950 in Mississippi
column7: from 41.7% in 1920 to 30.9% of the population in 1950 in Georgia
column8: from 38.9% in 1920 to 32.9% of the population in 1950 in Louisiana
column9: and from 38.4% in 1920 to 32.0% of the population in 1950 in Alabama. Based on the total populations in each of the four states
column10: only Georgia showed a net decrease (-143
column11: 188) in its African American population in 1950 compared to 1920.
